The Major offered him the other place if he wanted it. He 'd give him anything in the world. Bruce havin' it is the same as havin' it himself.
speaker: Sam Mills

utterance: He certainly ain' stingy. The way he looks after the old squa'r shows that, if nothin' else does. You know he went up thar and told him he 'd keep him comfort 'ble long as he lived?
speaker: Hall

utterance: Yes, so I hearn. Well, I tell you what sort of man the Major is. He 's got a tongue of flame; but he 's got a heart in his body as big as this worl', and he don't bear malice-not a minute.
speaker: Sam Mills

utterance: Brother, these are our two neighbors, Mr. Mills and Mr. Hall, of whom I have spoken to you.
speaker: Colonel Charles Landon

utterance: Oh, I know them.
speaker: Dr. Browne

utterance: Yes, we know him. There 's many a one down on Newfound knows him too.
speaker: Hall and Sam Mills

utterance: This is an old friend of yours, I believe?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: All I want, is that my husband may live here among his own people with the affection of such friends as he has been shown to have these last few weeks and that his friends may know him as I know him.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Oh! I think we know him on Newfound. And we know you too. And if you want anything on Newfound, all you got to do is to call on us and you can get it.
speaker: Hall and Sam Mills

utterance: Sam, s'pose we run him for governor, anyways. We can git him elected. He'll git every vote on Newfound.
speaker: Hall

utterance: I'm for him for president.
speaker: Sam Mills

utterance: Then we 'd have Miss' Landon in the White House, and that would be the best yet-only I don' know what we 'd do without her on Newfound.
speaker: Hall
